reviews.review_msg: Learned a lot from this course! 2 assignment papers, 1 term paper, and a final exam (short answer and essay question). Not bad if you're interested in the subject and are a good/okay writer. Lots of article readings, didn't really read the textbook though. (Textbook was available online + free)

Okay, it's not a good elective unless you are super interested in environment or you love to write. I found the syllabus pretty confusing too. Lecture slides can be a bit too broad/vague/irrelevant. He is an inspirational prof for sure, but it seems like he's more interested in his research areas than teaching. Not recommended as a GPA booster

Pros: Notes are reasonably clear. Exam was 100% related to class content. Passionate about what he teaches, and you can tell. Cons: Assignments/exam were marked with heavy criteria and exact essay conventions in mind (was not a writing course). Extremely boring lecturer; difficult to stay awake.

John is very nice, he has a monotone voice but still is good at lecturing. Provides good info & examples. Not a hard class & the papers were not hard to write. I didn't really find reading the online book to be important just pay attention in lecture. The final was pretty easy as long as you know what was said in lecture. Its a good 1st year class

Pretty cool class. John discusses relevant topics to resource management. He is really into this subject, has great everyday examples to help you understand the material better. He always encourages questions and always gives thoughtful responses. 2 smaller papers and 1 longer paper marked fair. Ppt handed out end the end of semester to help study

I hope to have John as a prof again in the future. Everything brought up in class was really relevant, and you can tell his knowledge goes far beyond resource management and geography. He's actually a really inspirational guy; he often rides his bike to school and sometimes brings up the ways he tries to live more sustainably. It was a great class!

John's passion for his field is evident. If you ask, on a sunny day he'll take you on a field trip to show you some work he's done around the city. He sends out lecture slides at the end to study for the final. Assignments are easy, you can all-nighter most of them and get a decent grade, so I expect if you try you'll do really well.

I can tell that he tried to be interesting, but he is just boring. He is a nice guy overall. You will have to rush during taking notes from his huge wordy slides. He DOES NOT provide any ppt from his lecture, so you better attend his lecture every time. Marking was fair, but you will need to put a lot of effort  for your assignment.
Expects you to take notes but doesn't leave the slides up long enough to copy. Says he will send out slides but doesn't. Talks way too much about himself. Monotone and boring.

Hard to pay attention to as he is monotone and rambles, but he does have interesting views that are worthwhile. Attendance is recommended to be mandatory as he does not send out slides. Final was easy, as long as you put some effort into studying
Monotone lectures and the powerpoints are incredibly wordy. Nice guy just boring..
Classes are super boring and he is very monotone and hard to understand

I really like. He's really nice, makes subtle jokes, is passionate about the lectures and assignments. He can be too quick, monotone, unclear but he'd be glad to meet with you and explain. I took a second class with him bcz he's so great :)

John's an incredibly smart guy. I was blown away at the beginning of the semester. He has a monotone voice which makes him hard to follow sometimes. Also, he doesn't provide lecture notes so I was always scrambling to get down what he was saying and usually ended up missing a lot of it. No midterm, and final was a little hard, but he's a good guy.

Good guy, genuine passion for what he teaches, but he's way too biased. He says he tries to present both sides, but he doesn't. When he does his portrayal of the other side is biased. He is a bit naive, doesn't understand a lot of technology, and is a bit boring to listen to. Although all things said and done, he's a decent prof. Just a bit naive.

Did no provide lecture slides, every class you had to race your typing against his speaking. Although the final was very clearly outlined, the other parts of the course was not. I do not see this course as a GPA booster.

One word: Boring! But you need to attend class to write his notes. First assignment: 4-page analysis, term paper: 8-10-page essay, last assignment (which he assigns the last week before finals): 4-page media analysis. This is a first-year course. Hello? Attend tutorial b/c that gives you a free 10%. Concepts are easy to grasp, though.
Very boring prof. Lectures were terrible and hard to follow. No real structure to the class and marked much harder than it should have been.

Boring class. Fair marker, slightly on the harder side though I must say. Content is not difficult to grasp but lots of reading and his monotone lectures dont help. Lectures are taped. Nice prof that does care about you though.

Okay prof. You can tell he loves the stuff he is talking about and believes it. Looooots of notes to take, mostly he reads off the slides. Hard to tell if he adds things in because you have to type at the speed of light to get everything down. Only recommend if you are interested in the subject.

Pretty brutal.  Guy can't lecture worth sh*t (but you have to go and listen to him read off his slides and frantically write/type it because he doesn't post them) and expects you to write fully formatted and cited research papers without actually teaching you how, despite being a 1st year class.  Passionate and knowledgeable about the field though.

A fair marker on all assignments and papers. Boring lectures with his monotone voice. The prof is very knowledgeable and knows his field very well. You should have a good environmental knowledge background if you want to take this class.
He's okay. Mediocre prof. But if you're smart and knowledgeable you should do fine in his classes.
He is a really nice guy and he loves the environment. He does speak in monotone but his lectures are really interesting.  Readings were relevant but a bit much.
Great class. Professor loves getting students involved. Would highly recommend.
